content.raw:
My initial idea was to pass the engine plugin through the `type` attribute. But there were 2 problems:

* This isn't the same usage as Gazebo-classic, so it could be confusing.
* Here we need 2 strings: the shared library and the class to be loaded, but there's only one field.

So at @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} 's suggestion, I put the engine details within the physics plugin tag.

But as I looked at the `type`, I was surprised to see that there was `ode` all over the place - because we don't use ODE :slight_smile: Ideally we'd remove this attribute, but it's currently required. So I changed it to `ignored` to avoid confusion, in case people think we're using ODE.

I'm open to suggestions.
content.html:
My initial idea was to pass the engine plugin through the type attribute. But there were 2 problems:

  • This isn't the same usage as Gazebo-classic, so it could be confusing.
  • Here we need 2 strings: the shared library and the class to be loaded, but there's only one field.

So at @Addisu Z. Taddese 's suggestion, I put the engine details within the physics plugin tag.

But as I looked at the type, I was surprised to see that there was ode all over the place - because we don't use ODE Ideally we'd remove this attribute, but it's currently required. So I changed it to ignored to avoid confusion, in case people think we're using ODE.

I'm open to suggestions.

content.raw: Ok, that is clear then \(note that the docs  [http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=physics#physics\_type](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=physics#physics_type) say that it is ode if it is left unspecified, but actually the attribute is required\). This problem of the `physics` element being Classic Gazebo-specific I guess it is another instance of [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/93/change-the-sdf-spec-to-make-less-gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/93/change-the-sdf-spec-to-make-less-gazebo) , i.e. a Classic Gazebo aspect that leaked in the SDF spec. Probably it could make sense to mention it there.
content.html: Ok, that is clear then (note that the docs http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=physics#physics_type say that it is ode if it is left unspecified, but actually the attribute is required). This problem of the physics element being Classic Gazebo-specific I guess it is another instance of https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issues/93/change-the-sdf-spec-to-make-less-gazebo , i.e. a Classic Gazebo aspect that leaked in the SDF spec. Probably it could make sense to mention it there.

content.raw:
this API instantiates a specific plugin by name, but you can also use `ignition::physics::FindFeatures3d<PhysicsPrivate::MinimumFeatureList>(pl);` to identify plugins within the specified shared library file that provide the desired features (see [hello_world.cc:37](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/src/cc5ab29e1d8d02a66538aec4cc58fd9e133667d4/examples/hello_world/hello_world.cc#lines-37))

what I'm trying to say is that we don't necessarily need to specify two strings; we can discover the class name
content.html:
this API instantiates a specific plugin by name, but you can also use ignition::physics::FindFeatures3d<PhysicsPrivate::MinimumFeatureList>(pl); to identify plugins within the specified shared library file that provide the desired features (see hello_world.cc:37)

what I'm trying to say is that we don't necessarily need to specify two strings; we can discover the class name

content.raw:
it would be nice to work on a design doc for this functionality as I have a few different ideas floating around

* it would be nice to retain the functionality of passing a command-line argument to choose a physics engine. we could use named physics blocks (ie [presets](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo11/test/worlds/presets.world))
* should we put physics plugins inside the `<physics>` block? then we could switch between physics implementations by switching between the physics presets
* I'm not sure the `//physics/@type` attribute makes sense for plugin-based physics implementations
content.html:
it would be nice to work on a design doc for this functionality as I have a few different ideas floating around

  • it would be nice to retain the functionality of passing a command-line argument to choose a physics engine. we could use named physics blocks (ie presets)
  • should we put physics plugins inside the <physics> block? then we could switch between physics implementations by switching between the physics presets
  • I'm not sure the //physics/@type attribute makes sense for plugin-based physics implementations

content.raw:
> command-line argument

+1. We already do this for logging, and should do something similar for physics.

> inside the <physics> block

I'm open to that idea, but that probably should go into Dome+.

> I'm not sure the //physics/@type attribute makes sense for plugin-based

Agreed, we may want to deprecate it.

> I have a few different ideas floating around

Do you think these are conflicting with this pull request? I think the environment variable can be retained even with your proposal. And we could have the `<engine>` tag on Blueprint and Citadel and deprecate it from Dome in favour of something else.
content.html:
command-line argument

+1. We already do this for logging, and should do something similar for physics.

inside the <physics> block

I'm open to that idea, but that probably should go into Dome+.

I'm not sure the //physics/@type attribute makes sense for plugin-based

Agreed, we may want to deprecate it.

I have a few different ideas floating around

Do you think these are conflicting with this pull request? I think the environment variable can be retained even with your proposal. And we could have the <engine> tag on Blueprint and Citadel and deprecate it from Dome in favour of something else.

content.raw:
Small comments that would not prevent the merge of this PR, that is already a huge improvement over the current state of things: 

The `Ignition Physics` tutorial page has currently no tutorial related on how to implement a new engine. If there is no plan to add a new one, probably it would be more informative to just link the source code of the dart backend implementation for inspiration. 

Furthermore, to develop a ignition-physics plugin that is meant to be used with ignition-gazebo, it is important to know the features/interfaces that a  physics plugin must implement. In ign-gazebo, this is defined by the `struct MinimumFeatureList` [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/939014abd905bdf5bd02176c09ce860e629f5d73/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc#lines-114](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/939014abd905bdf5bd02176c09ce860e629f5d73/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc#lines-114) , that is however just a private non-documented structure. As technically changing `struct MinimumFeatureList` would not break the ignition-gazebo libraries ABI but would break third party physics plugin from loading, another thing that it could make sense to mention is what is the policy regarding `struct MinimumFeatureList` \(for Citadel it could even be “we just break it whenever we like  : \) \). 

‌
content.html:
Small comments that would not prevent the merge of this PR, that is already a huge improvement over the current state of things:

The Ignition Physics tutorial page has currently no tutorial related on how to implement a new engine. If there is no plan to add a new one, probably it would be more informative to just link the source code of the dart backend implementation for inspiration.

Furthermore, to develop a ignition-physics plugin that is meant to be used with ignition-gazebo, it is important to know the features/interfaces that a physics plugin must implement. In ign-gazebo, this is defined by the struct MinimumFeatureList #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/939014abd905bdf5bd02176c09ce860e629f5d73/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc#lines-114 , that is however just a private non-documented structure. As technically changing struct MinimumFeatureList would not break the ignition-gazebo libraries ABI but would break third party physics plugin from loading, another thing that it could make sense to mention is what is the policy regarding struct MinimumFeatureList (for Citadel it could even be “we just break it whenever we like : ) ).

‌

content.raw:
Thanks, Silvio.

> The Ignition Physics tutorial page has currently no tutorial related on how to implement a new engine. If there is no plan to add a new one,

We're currently working on a 2nd physics engine plugin and documenting the process as we go. I added this link here on purpose with the hope that it will lead to useful information soon.

> struct MinimumFeatureList

Great point, I agree that this must be documented. Part of the work we're doing to integrate a 2nd engine may involve changing that minimum feature list though. That's why I'm reluctant to document it now. I suggest we leave this for a follow up pull request.

Then there may be a concern that when we change the required features, we may break existing plugins. So I think we should be careful that whatever changes we make are backwards compatible (i.e. we can't add more required features within a release for example). CC @{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} @{scpeters}
content.html:
Thanks, Silvio.

The Ignition Physics tutorial page has currently no tutorial related on how to implement a new engine. If there is no plan to add a new one,

We're currently working on a 2nd physics engine plugin and documenting the process as we go. I added this link here on purpose with the hope that it will lead to useful information soon.

struct MinimumFeatureList

Great point, I agree that this must be documented. Part of the work we're doing to integrate a 2nd engine may involve changing that minimum feature list though. That's why I'm reluctant to document it now. I suggest we leave this for a follow up pull request.

Then there may be a concern that when we change the required features, we may break existing plugins. So I think we should be careful that whatever changes we make are backwards compatible (i.e. we can't add more required features within a release for example). CC @Addisu Z. Taddese @Steve Peters

content.raw: Perfect, thanks **a lot** for working on this feature. Custom physics engine support is going to be extremely useful on its own, and a great selling point to convince people to switch to Ignition Gazebo.
content.html: Perfect, thanks a lot for working on this feature. Custom physics engine support is going to be extremely useful on its own, and a great selling point to convince people to switch to Ignition Gazebo.

content.raw:
> struct MinimumFeatureList

I would actually like to make the required features depend on the type of world and models that are loaded at run-time; there would still be a smaller set of minimum features (like `GetEntities`), but if there are no meshes, then we wouldn't need to require that feature. this makes the order of operations difficult as the sdf world file needs to be analyzed before loading the physics engine, and spawning a model dynamically after loading the physics engine could require a feature not provided by the current physics engine. also plugins might require specific features, so those would have to be serialized into the SDFormat xml tags somehow

but yes, we should document the MinimumFeatureList and treat it like part of the API with respect to semantic versioning
content.html:
struct MinimumFeatureList

I would actually like to make the required features depend on the type of world and models that are loaded at run-time; there would still be a smaller set of minimum features (like GetEntities), but if there are no meshes, then we wouldn't need to require that feature. this makes the order of operations difficult as the sdf world file needs to be analyzed before loading the physics engine, and spawning a model dynamically after loading the physics engine could require a feature not provided by the current physics engine. also plugins might require specific features, so those would have to be serialized into the SDFormat xml tags somehow

but yes, we should document the MinimumFeatureList and treat it like part of the API with respect to semantic versioning

content.raw: This sentence seems to suggest that the default behaviour is equivalent to `--physics-engine DART`, but the actual behaviour is something like `--physics-engine libignition-physics2-dartsim-plugin` , so perhaps adding a reference to how the arg gets converted to a full plugin name could be useful \(a classical point of confusion among users is wheter the `lib` prefix is implicit or explicit.
content.html: This sentence seems to suggest that the default behaviour is equivalent to --physics-engine DART, but the actual behaviour is something like --physics-engine libignition-physics2-dartsim-plugin , so perhaps adding a reference to how the arg gets converted to a full plugin name could be useful (a classical point of confusion among users is wheter the lib prefix is implicit or explicit.

content.raw:
Upon testing I noticed a couple of things:

* After sourcing the workspace, I only figured out how to use the command line version to choose physics engine, which seems to work without setting the environment variable.
* `helloworld` plugin has to be invoked by setting environment variable, even with command line option
* ~~Not sure if this inconsistent behaviour was intended or caused by my mistakes during testing.~~

\[Edit\] Actually that makes sense with `colcon build` and sourcing workspace. Confirming this branch works with all three engines as intended.

Terminal results see below

`dartsim`:

```
$  ign gazebo -v 2 -r shapes.sdf --physics-engine ignition-physics-dartsim-plugin
[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/ComponentInspector/ComponentInspector.qml:161: ReferenceError: ComponentsModel is not defined
```

`tpe`:

```
$ ign gazebo -v 2 -r shapes.sdf --physics-engine ignition-physics-tpe-plugin    
[Wrn] [Physics.cc:368] Plugin [ignition::physics::tpeplugin::Plugin] misses required features:
- N8ignition7physics17GetJointFromModelE
- N8ignition7physics18GetBasicJointStateE
- N8ignition7physics18SetBasicJointStateE
- N8ignition7physics23GetBasicJointPropertiesE
- N8ignition7physics26AddLinkExternalForceTorqueE
- N8ignition7physics30GetContactsFromLastStepFeatureE
- N8ignition7physics30SetJointVelocityCommandFeatureE
- N8ignition7physics3sdf17ConstructSdfJointE
[Err] [Physics.cc:373] Failed to load a valid physics engine from [/home/claire/citadel_ws/install/lib/ign-physics-2/engine-plugins/libignition-physics-tpe-plugin.so].
[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/ComponentInspector/ComponentInspector.qml:161: ReferenceError: ComponentsModel is not defined
```

`helloworld`:

```
IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 2 build/rolling_box.sdf
[Wrn] [Physics.cc:368] Plugin [mock::HelloWorldPlugin] misses required features:
- N8ignition7physics11ForwardStepE
- N8ignition7physics16GetLinkFromModelE
- N8ignition7physics16GetShapeFromLinkE
- N8ignition7physics17GetJointFromModelE
- N8ignition7physics17GetModelFromWorldE
- N8ignition7physics18GetBasicJointStateE
- N8ignition7physics18GetWorldFromEngineE
- N8ignition7physics18LinkFrameSemanticsE
- N8ignition7physics18SetBasicJointStateE
- N8ignition7physics20FindFreeGroupFeatureE
- N8ignition7physics20RemoveModelFromWorldE

- N8ignition7physics23GetBasicJointPropertiesE
- N8ignition7physics26AddLinkExternalForceTorqueE
- N8ignition7physics30GetContactsFromLastStepFeatureE
- N8ignition7physics30SetJointVelocityCommandFeatureE
- N8ignition7physics3sdf16ConstructSdfLinkE
- N8ignition7physics3sdf17ConstructSdfJointE
- N8ignition7physics3sdf17ConstructSdfModelE

[Err] [Physics.cc:373] Failed to load a valid physics engine from [/home/claire/citadel_ws/src/ign-physics/examples/hello_world_plugin/build/libHelloWorldPlugin.so].
```

content.html:
Upon testing I noticed a couple of things:

  • After sourcing the workspace, I only figured out how to use the command line version to choose physics engine, which seems to work without setting the environment variable.
  • helloworld plugin has to be invoked by setting environment variable, even with command line option
  • Not sure if this inconsistent behaviour was intended or caused by my mistakes during testing.

[Edit] Actually that makes sense with colcon build and sourcing workspace. Confirming this branch works with all three engines as intended.

Terminal results see below
